topics.title: Housing squeeze & rents
topics.description: Record-low vacancy rates in Zürich; new ideas like giving priority to Swiss/long-term residents are stirring backlash vs. fair-housing concerns.

candidates.name: Lina Meier
candidates.character: Progressive (left-leaning). Prioritises a stronger social safety net and public services; backs premium relief in LAMal and more cost controls; pro–cooperative/affordable housing; supports closer EU ties incl. a framework agreement; ambitious climate policy (net-zero 2050, public transport, renewables); liberal on migration/asylum with focus on integration; progressive taxation and childcare support; values direct democracy with citizen initiatives to expand social programs. Determined to win a governing mandate by mobilising the urban base while reassuring centrist swing voters with pragmatic, costed plans.

initial_policy_positions.topic_1: The housing squeeze in Zürich demands immediate action. I support a significant increase in the construction of affordable and cooperative housing, alongside rent controls and stricter regulations to protect tenants. We must also ensure fair housing practices and reject proposals that prioritize residents based on nationality or length of residency, as this undermines our commitment to an inclusive society.

candidates.name: Markus Keller
candidates.character: Conservative (right-leaning). Emphasises free markets and limited government; prefers competition and efficiency in healthcare (managed care, higher deductibles choice) over new subsidies; pro-property rights and deregulation to spur private housing supply; EU-sceptical—prefers bilateral deals without automatic legal alignment; energy security via technology neutrality incl. new-gen nuclear; strict migration controls with faster procedures; supports tax relief and individual taxation; prioritises neutrality, security, and fiscal discipline. Focused on winning a centre-right mandate by uniting conservatives and persuading cost-conscious moderates with a stability-and-competence message.

initial_policy_positions.topic_1: The housing shortage in Zürich demands a market-based solution. We need to remove bureaucratic hurdles and streamline planning processes to encourage private developers to build more housing, thereby increasing supply and easing price pressures. Prioritizing Swiss or long-term residents is discriminatory; instead, we should focus on measures that benefit everyone, such as deregulating the housing market and protecting property rights.
